channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Summer is calling… Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international financial company with offices around the world. With a global presence and the kind of growth that would make a beanstalk blush, they’re looking to expand their team. If you’re a Perl programmer with a side interest in online trading, you’ll be a natural in this role. Looking for Perl developers comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack and Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Forget the carrot and stick! Perl role in London
item.description: As a company at the top of their game, our client is looking for a Perl developer who is similarly eager to be the best. You’ll thrive in an environment where you work independently and in teams, and you enjoy writing code with a variety of languages. Your knowledge of JS and experience with frameworks like React will round out your understanding of MySQL and NoSQL databases like Google BigTable.

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Our client is one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re not saying you shouldn’t spend money, but if you’re going to splash out on the latest gear, why not get the best price? Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: Perl Superheroes Wanted! Remote Perl within US time zone
item.description: Does your boss treat you like a Perl superhero? If the answer is no, we’ve got a role open that’ll inspire you to leap a tall building with excitement. Best of all, this position is 100% remote. Required skills: Strong Modern Perl - Specifically Catalyst/Mojolicious and DBIx::Class

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: A global leader in machine intelligence matching job seekers with their perfect career: our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer whose passion for NLP is matched only by their interest in Machine Intelligence and their ability to drive quality improvements, measurement standards, and error analysis processes for the NLP framework.

item.title: Regexp::Grammars parse text with markup or markdown
item.description: Parsing text with markup (or markdown) is not easy. It took me several days to wrap my head around this, but eventually I think I've figured it out.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 121: Travelling Bit
item.description: Roger implementation of The Travelling Salesman task is very impressive. Well done. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 121
item.description: Luis went ahead of what was asked in the task of The Travelling Salesman and gave us lots of extra goodies. You don't want to miss out.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 121: bits and salesman
item.description: Luca didn't like The Travelling Salesman task but still managed to present us the solution in a simple and easy way to follow. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 121: Invert Bit
item.description: Laurent only attempted the Invert Bit task as he was too busy with his other commitments. Glad he shared the blog with us. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #120
item.description: As always James came up with performance matrix solution. I loved his solution to The Travelling Salesman, so easy to follow. Thanks.

item.title: PWC121 - The Travelling Salesman
item.description: Flavio is one of the few selected members who attempted to solve The Travelling Salesman task. It well documented for anyone to read. Thanks.

item.title: PWC121 - Invert Bit
item.description: Flavio seems to be enjoying Raku lot more than Perl these days. You have made good progress, good luck.

item.title: Bitty Tours: Perl Weekly Challenge #121
item.description: Dave presented us a full fledged solution to The Travelling Salesman task with good solid background. Thanks.

item.title: Mr. Brush Man, That One’s Upside Down!
item.description: Colin blog appears to be a text book on the topic. So nicely explained. Well done Colin.

item.title: Inverted Salesman with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne pictorial description is unbeatable, specially the bitwise operation. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 121: The Travelling Salesman
item.description: Really cool explanation of the task and solution itself makes it so easy to follow. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 121: Invert Bit
item.description: Abigail one liner is back in action with bitwise operation. Nice little hack.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 121
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Invert Bit" and "The Travelling Salesman" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 122
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Average of Stream" and "Basketball Points". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Call for Grants: July 2021 Round
item.description: The application deadline for this round is 23:59 July 27, 2021, UTC.

item.title: Grant Proposal: Maintaining Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell)
Finding a shared vision of Perl
item.description: The Perl Foundation (TPF) is conducting research to identify the shared values of the Perl community, and their vision of the Perl ecosystem in years to come.

item.title: Survey launch
item.description: Dr. Ann Barcomb of the University of Calgary is conducting research to understand episodic, or occasional, participation in the Perl and Raku communities, in collaboration with The Perl Foundation.

item.title: More commenting... maybe?
item.description: My code might use some more commenting, maybe? - A reflection on The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Web nostalgia: MojoX::Mechanize
item.description: Back when the web was simpler, the clients were dumb and Perl ruled as the server frontend, interfaces were IMHO more clearly defined and somehow standardized.

item.title: Adding a Preview Window to Your Tab Completion
Adding Tab Completion to Your Favourite CLI Programs
Taming the Moose: Picking the best way to subclass Perl methods
item.description: The override keyword in Perl’s Moose object system is a nice bit of code-as-documentation.

item.title: Finding Vim snippets in Bash
item.description: A little Bash program (with completions) to show Vim snippets.

item.title: Release 1.55 of perl-workflow, a minor feature release
Mojolicious Music Player
item.description: Can you build an audio player from perl Mojolicious?

item.title: #521 - Floods in Perl
item.description:
Hi there,

This week we saw the tremendous and devastating power of nature in Europe as well. The Guardian even mentioned the Moselle River at Perl in Germany. The place where Liz and Wendy attempted to re-unite the Perl 5 and Perl 6 communities as well. That was not very successful.

I was wondering what can we do?

I know a few members of the Perl community who are also volunteer firefighters. Some of them might have taken part in the rescue efforts maybe even risking their own lives. That a very generous way of helping others and helping the world when disaster strikes.

I know a few other members of the Perl community who make an effort to reduce their own carbon footprint by traveling by bike and train only. That can help postpone the disasters and if enough people do them might even prevent the disasters.

What do you do? What examples could we follow to help when disaster strikes? What could ew do to try to avoid the disasters in the first place? Write about it in a blog and send the link to me!

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
